original_data.question: Six hours after birth, a newborn boy is evaluated for tachypnea. He was delivered at 41 weeks' gestation via Caesarian section and the amniotic fluid was meconium-stained. His respiratory rate is 75/min. Physical examination shows increased work of breathing. X-rays of the abdomen and chest show no abnormalities. Echocardiography shows elevated pulmonary artery pressure. He is started on an inhaled medication that increases smooth muscle cGMP, and there is immediate improvement in his tachypnea and oxygenation status. Three hours later, the newborn is tachypneic and there is blue-grey discoloration of the lips, fingers, and toes. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this infant's cyanosis?

options.A: Increase in concentration of serum myoglobin

model_response:
This infant's initial improvement after inhaled medication that increases smooth muscle cGMP suggests that he has a reactive pulmonary artery hypertension. The blue-grey discoloration of the lips, fingers, and toes suggests that he has developed a severe metabolic acidosis. Increased smooth muscle cGMP relaxes the pulmonary vasculature, which decreases pulmonary artery pressure. This can lead to a steal phenomenon whereby blood flow to the pulmonary circulation decreases, leaving a larger volume of blood in the systemic circulation. If the ductus arteriosus were to close, this would only exacerbate the problem by preventing any mixing of oxygenated and deoxygenated blood. The other choices are not related to the treatment of this infant's condition.

###Answer: OPTION A IS CORRECT.</s><s>

question_entities.definition: Every six hours.
The process of giving birth to one or more offspring.
An infant during the first 28 days after birth.
Abnormal increase of rate of breathing.
Any period of seven consecutive days.
Extraction of the FETUS by means of abdominal HYSTEROTOMY.

A clear, yellowish liquid that envelopes the FETUS inside the sac of AMNION. In the first trimester, it is likely a transudate of maternal or fetal plasma. In the second trimester, amniotic fluid derives primarily from fetal lung and kidney. Cells or substances in this fluid can be removed for prenatal diagnostic tests (AMNIOCENTESIS).
Presence of meconium into amniotic fluid.
The rate of breathing (inhalation and exhalation) measured within in a unit time, usually expressed as breaths per minute.
Systematic and thorough inspection of the patient for physical signs of disease or abnormality.
A radiographic procedure using the emission of x-rays to form an image of the structure penetrated by the radiation.
That portion of the body that lies between the THORAX and the PELVIS.
The upper part of the trunk between the NECK and the ABDOMEN. It contains the chief organs of the circulatory and respiratory systems. (From Stedman, 25th ed)
Ultrasonic recording of the size, motion, and composition of the heart and surrounding tissues. The standard approach is transthoracic.
An elevated level or position or degree; greater than normal in degree or intensity or amount.
Blood pressure in the pulmonary artery.
Drugs intended for human or veterinary use, presented in their finished dosage form. Included here are materials used in the preparation and/or formulation of the finished dosage form.

Unstriated and unstriped muscle, one of the muscles of the internal organs, blood vessels, hair follicles, etc. Contractile elements are elongated, usually spindle-shaped cells with centrally located nuclei. Smooth muscle fibers are bound together into sheets or bundles by reticular fibers and frequently elastic nets are also abundant. (From Stedman, 25th ed)

Guanosine cyclic 3',5'-(hydrogen phosphate). A guanine nucleotide containing one phosphate group which is esterified to the sugar moiety in both the 3'- and 5'-positions. It is a cellular regulatory agent and has been described as a second messenger. Its levels increase in response to a variety of hormones, including acetylcholine, insulin, and oxytocin and it has been found to activate specific protein kinases. (From Merck Index, 11th ed)
A condition superior to an earlier condition.
Abnormal increase of rate of breathing.
The metabolic process of all living cells (animal and plant) in which oxygen is used to provide a source of energy for the cell.
An infant during the first 28 days after birth.
A change in color that deviates from the norm or outwith the bounds of what is considered normal.
Either of the two fleshy, full-blooded margins of the mouth.
Four or five slender jointed digits in humans and primates, attached to each HAND.
Any one of five terminal digits of the vertebrate FOOT.
A child between 1 and 23 months of age.
A bluish or purplish discoloration of the skin and mucous membranes due to an increase in the amount of deoxygenated hemoglobin in the blood or a structural defect in the hemoglobin molecule.
